encodingDesc.p: The electronic text for this file was prepared by Whitman Archive staff, who transcribed the text from a representation of the original (e.g., digital scan or other electronic reproduction, microfilm copy).

body.head: Specimen Days and Collect
Walt Whitman's Prose.
body.p: A collection of the prose writings of Walt Whitman has been issued under the peculiar title,“Specimen Days and Collect,” by Rees, Welsh & Co. of Philadelphia, the publishing-house which issued “Leaves of Grass” after the Massachusetts Court had placed its anathema upon it. To the general reader Whitman’s prose will be far more attractive than his poetry, although it shows many of the same features. If the good passages could be culled out from the mass of rubbish, it would be a great saving of time; but as it is, after reading several pages of tinged commonplace, one comes upon a bit of prose, filled with the spirit of poetry and far-reaching suggestion; or one finds a sketch of nature which shows the same kinship with all growing things that Thoreau possessed. The first half of the book will be found the best. It contains Walt’s diary when he was a hospital nurse during the Rebellion, and there is much pathos in many of the entries. The notes of rambles about new York—contributed to several periodicals during the last two or three years—also contain many good things. One of the curiosities of the book is the preface to the first edition of “Leaves of grass”—which, it must be confessed, is better reading then the poems themselves. In an appendix are included a half-dozen pieces written in early youth. They are worth notice only because they show that Whitman’s peculiar style was not adopted in his youth, but was the result of mature deliberation.
